sen.e: The major opinion among the scholars is based on the part in the preface to "Kojiki" '後葉(のちのよ)に流(つた)へむと欲ふ', to be understood as 'a collection of poems that should be handed down forever' by taking 葉 as 'generations to come'.

The most established opinion among scholars is based on the following part in the preface to the "Kojiki", '後葉(のちのよ)に流(つた)へむと欲ふ', which is understood to mean 'a collection of poems that should be handed down forever', taking 葉 as 'generations to come'.

sen.j: 歌体は、短歌・長歌・旋頭歌（せどうか）の三種に区別されている。
sen.e: The poetic form is categorized into three of Tanka, Choka, and Sedoka.
There are three categories of poetry: tanka, choka, and sedoka.
There are three categories of Japanese poetry: Tanka, choka, and sedoka.

sen.j: 短い句は五音節、長い句は七音節からなる。
sen.e: A short line consists of 5 syllables, and a long line consists of 7 syllables.
A short line consists of five syllables, and a long line consists of seven syllables.
A short line consists of five syllables, and a long line consists of seven syllables.

sen.j: 短歌は、五七五七七の五句からなるもの。
sen.e: Tanka consists of 5 lines in the pattern of 5-7-5-7-7 syllables.
Tanka consist of five lines in the pattern 5-7-5-7-7.
Tanka consist of five lines in the pattern 5-7-5-7-7.

sen.j: 長歌は、十数句から二十数句までのものが普通であり、五七を長く続け、最後をとくに五七七という形式で結ぶもの。
sen.e: Choka generally consists of 10 to 20 lines with 5-7 syllables alternatively and a couplet of 7 syllable at the end.
Choka generally consist of ten to twenty lines with alternatively five and seven syllables and a couplet of seven syllables at the end.
Choka generally consist of more than 10 to more than 20 lines with alternatively five and seven syllables and a couplet of seven syllables at the end.

sen.j: 長歌の後に、別に、一首か数首添える短歌は反歌と呼ばれている。
sen.e: One or several tanka separately added to Choka are called Hanka.
One or several tanka appended to a choka is called a hanka.

sen.j: 旋頭歌は、短長の一回の組み合わせに長一句を添えた形を片歌といい、この片歌の形式を二回繰り返した形である。
sen.e: Sedoka consists of two Katauta, which consists of a set of tanka and choka with one more choka added.
Sedoka consist of two katauta, which in turn consist of a set of tanka and choka with one more choka added.
Sedoka consist of two katauta, which in turn consist of a set of tanka and choka with one more choka added.

sen.j: 頭三句と同じ形を尾三句で繰り返すことから旋頭歌とついたといわれる。
sen.e: It is considered the name Sedoka originated from its form that the first three lines are repeated at the last three lines.

sen.j: 代表的歌人は、自然の風景を描き出すような叙景歌に優れた山部赤人（やまべのあかひと）、風流で叙情にあふれる長歌を詠んだ大伴旅人、人生の苦悩と下層階級への暖かいまなざしをそそいだ山上憶良（やまのうえのおくら）、伝説のなかに本来の姿を見出す高橋虫麻呂（むしまろ）、女性の哀感を歌にした大伴坂上郎女（さかのうえのいらつめ）などである。
sen.e: The representative poets are YAMABE no Akahito who wrote descriptive poetry to depict natural landscape; OOTOMO no Tabito who wrote Choka full of elegance and lyricism; YAMANOUE no Okura who wrote poems showing sympathy to those who had hard times and the lower-ranked people; TAKAHASHI no Mushimaro who wrote poems to show what is alluded in the legends; and SAKANOUE no Iratsume who composed poems with women's pathos.

There are several poets representative of this period, such as YAMABE no Akahito who wrote descriptive poetry depicting scenery and landscape, OOTOMO no Tabito who wrote choka full of elegance and lyricism, YAMANOUE no Okura who wrote poems sympathetic to those facing hard times and the lower strata of society, TAKAHASHI no Mushimaro who wrote poems to show the true nature of various legends, and SAKANOUE no Iratsume who composed poems with the pathos of a woman.

There are several poets representative of this period, such as YAMABE no Akahito who wrote descriptive poetry depicting scenery and landscape, OTOMO no Tabito who wrote choka full of elegance and lyricism, YAMANOUE no Okura who wrote poems sympathetic to those facing hard times and the lower strata of society, TAKAHASHI no Mushimaro who wrote poems to show the true nature of various legends, and OTOMO no SAKANOUE no Iratsume who composed poems with the pathos of a woman.

sen.j: 第4期は、759年（天平宝字3）までで、代表歌人は旅人の子で大伴家持・笠郎女（かさのいらつめ）・大伴坂上郎女（おおとものさかのうえのいらつめ）・橘諸兄（たちばなのもろえ）・中臣宅守（なかとみのやかもり）・狭野弟上娘子（さののおとがみのおとめ）・湯原王などである。
sen.e: The fourth period is to 759 and its representative poets are OOTOMO no Yakamochi, a son of Tabito, KASA no Iratsume, OOTOMO SAKANOUE no Iratsume, TACHIBANA no Moroe, NAKATOMI no Yakamori, SANO no Otogaminootome, and Yuhara no Ookimi.

sen.j: 歌の作者層を見てみると、皇族や貴族から中・下級官人などに波及していき、作者不明の歌は畿内の下級官人や庶民の歌と見られ、また東歌や防人歌などに見られるように庶民にまで広がっていったことが分かる。
sen.e: The poets ranges from the Imperial family and nobles to middle ranked and lower ranked court officials, and the anonymous poems are considered to have been wrote by lower ranked court officials and commoners in Kinai (Kyoto, Osaka, and Nara) area, and it is apparent from Azumauta and Sakimoriuta, an increasing number of the commoners began to wrote poems.

The poets range from the Imperial family and nobles to middle ranked and lower ranked court officials, and the anonymous poems are considered to have been written by lower ranked court officials and commoners in the Kinai (Kyoto, Osaka, and Nara) area, and it is apparent from the volumes entitled Azumauta and Sakimoriuta that an increasing number of commoners began to wrote poems.

The poets range from the Imperial Family and nobles to middle ranked and lower ranked court officials, and the anonymous poems are considered to have been written by lower ranked court officials and commoners in the Kinai (Kyoto, Osaka, and Nara) area, and it is apparent from the volumes entitled Azumauta and Sakimori no uta that an increasing number of commoners began to wrote poems.

sen.j: さらに、地域的には、宮廷周辺から京や畿内、東国というふうに範囲が時代と共に拡大されていったと考えられる。
sen.e: From the viewpoint of regions, composing of poetry was spread from the neighborhood of the Imperial Palace to Kyoto, to Kinai, and to Togoku, the eastern Provinces, as years went by.

sen.e: As the Japanese syllabary had not been established at the time of "Manyoshu", it was written in a unique writing system called Manyogana.

sen.j: つまり、漢字の意味とは関係なく、漢字の音訓だけを借用して日本語を表記しようとしたのである。
sen.e: Specifically, the Manyogana writing system was for expressing the Japanese language by using only the Chinese pronunciations so that the letters had nothing to do with the meanings of the Chinese characters.

Specifically, the manyogana writing system was for expressing the Japanese language through using only the Chinese pronunciations of the characters, with the result that the sounds had nothing to do with the meanings of the characters.

Specifically, the manyo-gana writing system was for expressing the Japanese language through using only the Chinese pronunciations of the characters, with the result that the sounds had nothing to do with the meanings of the characters.

sen.j: その意味では、万葉仮名は、漢字を用いながらも、日本人による日本人のための最初の文字であったと言えよう。

sen.j: 万葉仮名は、奈良時代の終末には、字形を少し崩して、画数も少ない文字が多用されるようになり、平安時代に至るとますますその傾向が強まり、少しでも速く、また効率よく文字が書けるようにと、字形を極端に簡略化（草略）したり字画を省略（省画）したりするようになった。
sen.e: In the end of Nara period, Manyogana was developed through slight transformations into the characters with less stroke counts to be used in much more occasions; and during the Heian period, they were further developed into the characters with extremely simplified figures (known as Soryaku) or the characters with stroke counts partly omitted (known as Shokaku) to be written more faster and more effectively.

At the end of the Nara Period manyogana was developed through slight transformations of the characters, with characters with fewer strokes being increasingly used, and during the Heian Period they were further developed into characters with extremely simplified figures (known as soryaku) or characters with some strokes partly omitted (known as shokaku) which could be written faster and more efficiently.

At the end of the Nara period manyo-gana was developed through slight transformations of the characters, with characters with fewer strokes being increasingly used, and during the Heian period they were further developed into characters with extremely simplified figures (known as soryaku) or characters with some strokes partly omitted (known as shokaku) which could be written faster and more efficiently.

Manyo-gana and dialects

sen.j: 『万葉集』には「東風 越俗語、東風謂之安由乃可是也」（巻17・4017番）のように、当時の方言についてそれと明示した記述があるが、いちいち方言と銘打ってはいなくても、実は大量の方言が記録されている。
sen.e: In "Manyoshu", some of the then dialects are indicated as such like '東風 越俗語、東風謂之安由乃可是也' (Volume 17, 4017), but a great many dialects are recorded even they are not indicated as such.

In the Manyoshu some of the dialects of the time are indicated such as '東風 越俗語、東風謂之安由乃可是也' (volume seventeen, 4017), but a great many other dialects are recorded even though they are not indicated as such.
sen.cmt: Punctuation, grammar. The Japanese text needs a brief explanation I think.
sen.e: In the "Manyoshu" some of the dialects of the time are indicated such as 'Ayunokaze Etsu no Kuniburi no kotoba, Higashikaze wo Ayunokaze to iu' (In the Etsu dialect, the word 'higashikaze' [an east wind] is 'ayunokaze,' 東風 越俗語、東風謂之安由乃可是也) (volume 17, 4017), but a great many other dialects are recorded even though they are not indicated as such.
sen.cmt: 英訳などを補足しました。

sen.j: 即ち、巻14の東歌（あずまうた）と巻20の防人歌（さきもりうた）である。
sen.e: Specifically, Azumauta in Volume 14 and Sakimoriuta in Volume 20 are the examples.
Specific examples of this can be found in volume fourteen (Azumauta) and volume twenty (Sakimoriuta).
Specific examples of this can be found in volume 14 (Azumauta) and volume 20 (Sakimoriuta).

sen.j: 東歌は東国地方の歌の意で、東国（今の関東・東北地方から東海地方まで含まれる）に伝わる歌を収集し、どの国の歌か判明している歌（勘国歌。90首+5首）と不明の歌（未勘国歌。140首+3首）に二分して収録している。
sen.e: Azumauta, meaning poems from Togoku region, covers poems handed down in Togoku--which covers the present Kanto region, Tohoku region, and Tokai region--divided into two groups of the poems with their birthplaces were known called 'Kankokuka' (90 + 5 poems) and the poems with their birthplaces were unknown called 'Mikankokuka' (140 + 3 poems).

Azumauta, meaning poems from the Togoku region, covers poems handed down in Togoku, which covers the present Kanto region, Tohoku region, and Tokai region, divided into two groups for poems with their place of origin known called kankokuka (ninety-five poems) and for poems where their place of origin was unknown called mikankokuka (143 poems).
sen.cmt: Grammar, punctuation, changed for clarity. I have amalgamated the totals of each kind of poem as it is unclear as to what "90 + 5" means.
sen.e: Azumauta, meaning poems from the Togoku region, covers poems handed down in Togoku, which covers the present Kanto region, Tohoku region, and Tokai region, divided into two groups for poems with their place of origin known called kankokuka (90 and 5 poems) and for poems where their place of origin was unknown called mikankokuka (140 and 3 poems).

sen.j: 多くの歌で上代の東国方言が多用されており、歌の成立年代や作者の出自、記録の経緯が一切不明という問題点はあるにしても、古代の方言の具体的な記録として重要な位置を占める。
sen.e: As the dialects in the Togoku region in the ancient times are frequently used in most of the poems, the category 'Azumauta' is placed in an important position as a specific record of the ancient dialects, even though they have a problem in that none of the composed years of the poems, composers' profiles, how they were contained is unknown.

As the dialects of the Togoku region of the period are frequently used in most of the poems the 'Azumauta' has an imortant position as a specific record of these ancient dialects, even though the year the poems were composed, the profile of the composers, and how they were recorded remain unknown.

As the dialects of the Togoku region of the period are frequently used in most of the poems the 'Azumauta' has an important position as a specific record of these ancient dialects, even though the year the poems were composed, the profile of the composers, and how they were recorded remain unknown.

sen.j: また、分量の豊富さも魅力である。
sen.e: Also its large quantity is considered the merit of Azumauta..
Also the large quantity of the poems it contains is seen as a particular merit of the collection.
Also the large quantity of the poems it contains is seen as a particular merit of the collection.

sen.j: 防人歌は東国から徴集された防人の詠んだ歌の意で、巻13や巻14にも少量見えるが、最も著名なのは巻20に「天平勝宝七歳乙未二月、相替遣筑紫諸国防人等歌」として84首収録されているものである。
sen.e: Sakimoriuta, meaning poems composed by coast guards conscripted from Togoku, are contained in Volumes 13 and 14 by a small number and contained in Volume 20 by 84 under the title of '天平勝宝七歳乙未二月、相替遣筑紫諸国防人等歌'.

A small number of sakimoriuta, poems composed by coast guards conscripted from Togoku, can be found in volumes thirteen and fourteen but the majority (eighty-four in total) appear in volume twenty under the title of '天平勝宝七歳乙未二月、相替遣筑紫諸国防人等歌'.
sen.cmt: Punctuation, grammar. The Japanese text needs a brief explanation I think.
sen.e: A small number of sakimoriuta, poems composed by coast guards conscripted from Togoku, can be found in volumes 13 and 14 but the majority (84 poems in total) appear in volume 20 under the title of 'In August, 749, the poems of Sakimori and others dispatched in turns to the provinces in Chikushi' (天平勝宝七歳乙未二月、相替遣筑紫諸国防人等歌).

sen.j: これは天平勝宝7歳（755年）に徴集された防人の詠んだ歌を、防人を率いてきた各国の部領使（ことりづかい）に命じて記録、上進させたもので、拙劣歌として半数近く（82首）が棄てられてはいるものの、採用された歌については作者の名前から出身国（国によっては郡名まで）まで逐一記されている。
sen.e: For the 84 poems, captains to lead the coast guards who were conscripted in 755 from respective provinces were commanded to record and submit the poems composed by the coast guards; among the originally collected poems, 82 poems, almost half of them, were abandoned as unskillful, and the selected poems were registered with the composers' names, and the provinces they came from (the counties they came from in some cases were also included).

Regarding these eighty-four poems, captains of the coast guards who were conscripted in 755 from each province were commanded to record and submit the poems composed by the coast guards; among the originally collected poems, eighty-two, or almost half of them, were not included as they were felt to be not skillful enough, and the selected poems were registered with the composers' names, and the provinces they came from (the counties they came from in some cases were also included).

Regarding these poems, captains of the Sakimori who were conscripted in 755 from each province were commanded to record and submit the poems composed by the Sakimori guards; among the originally collected poems, 82, or almost half of them, were not included as they were felt to be not skillful enough, and the selected poems were registered with the composers' names, and the provinces they came from (the counties they came from in some cases were also included).

sen.j: しかも、万葉集に採録するにあたって、内容はもちろん万葉仮名表記に至るまで上進時のままで改変されていない可能性が高く、東国方言資料としての価値は東歌を凌駕するものと評価されている。
sen.e: As the poems were highly possible to have been contained in Manyoshu as they were not only the contents but also their expression with Manyogana, Sakimoriuta is evaluated much higher than Azumauta as the materials on the dialects in Togoku region.

Also, as the content of the poems was expressed in Manyogana when the poems were transcribed to the Manyoshu, Sakimoriuta is evaluated much higher than Azumauta as a valuable resource in relation to the dialects of the Togoku region.

Also, as the content of the poems was expressed in Manyo-gana when the poems were transcribed to the Manyoshu, Sakimoriuta is evaluated much higher than Azumauta as a valuable resource in relation to the dialects of the Togoku region.

sen.e: (I could not untie the cord in the daytime, but easily untie in the evening, because probably I'll see my husband.)

sen.e: As it is apparent from the above poems, not a small number of the dialects in Togoku region recorded in "Manyoshu" are common with the modern dialects in the eastern Japan.

As can be seen from the above poems, quite a few of the dialects of the Togoku region recorded in the "Manyoshu" have correlations with the modern dialects found in eastern Japan.

sen.j: 中でも否定の助動詞「～なふ」や命令の終止法に付く終助詞「～ろ」は、現代東日本方言の「～ない」「～ろ」に連なる可能性が指摘されている。
sen.e: Among others, it is pointed out that the negative auxiliary verbs '-nafu' and the sentence-final particle '-ro' that follows the imperative base form can be associated with '-nai' and '-ro' in the modern dialects in the eastern Japan.

Taking a couple of examples, the negative auxiliary verbs '-nafu' and the sentence-ending particle '-ro' that follows the imperative base form can be associated with '-nai' and '-ro' in the modern dialects of eastern Japan.

Taking a couple of examples, the negative auxiliary verbs '-nafu' and the sentence-ending particle '-ro' that follows the imperative base form can be associated with '-nai' and '-ro' in the modern dialects of eastern Japan.

sen.j: また、東国方言の四段動詞と形容詞の連体形は、「立と月」「愛（かな）しけ妹（いも）」のように中央語とは異なる独特の語形を取るが、八丈島で話される八丈方言は「書こ時」「高け山」のように、上代東国方言と同様の語形を取ることで知られている。
sen.e: The quadrigraded conjugation verbs and the attributive form of adjectives of the dialects in Togoku region like 'Tatsu to tsuki' 'Kanashike imo' take unique forms different from the standard Japanese; on the other hand, it is known that the Hachijo dialect spoken in Hachijojima island like 'Kakotoki' 'Takake yama' takes the same form as that of the ancient dialects in Togoku region.

The quadrigraded conjugation verbs and the attributive form of adjectives of the dialects in the Togoku region such as 'Tatsu to tsuki' and 'Kanashike imo' take unique forms different from the standard Japanese; on the other hand, it is known that the Hachijo dialect spoken in Hachijojima island such as 'Kakotoki' and 'Takake yama' takes the same form as that of the ancient dialects of the Togoku region.

The quadrigraded conjugation verbs and the attributive form of adjectives of the dialects in the Togoku region such as 'Ta to tsuku' ('Tatsu to tsuki' [the new moon comes]) and 'Kanashike imo' ('Itoshii Imoto' [my sweet younger sister]) take unique forms different from the standard Japanese; on the other hand, it is known that the Hachijo dialect spoken in Hachijo-jima island such as 'Kakotoki' ('Kakutoki' [when man writes]) and 'Takake yama' ('Takaki Yama' [a high mountain]) takes the same form as that of the ancient dialects of the Togoku region.

sen.j: 日本語に方言は数あれど、このような活用を残すのは八丈方言だけである。
sen.e: Among a large number of dialects in the Japanese language, only the Hachijo dialect takes this kind of form.

sen.j: 万葉集には「いさな（鯨魚）」を詠んだ歌が詠われているが、いさなとは鯨魚、鯨名、勇魚、不知魚、伊佐魚とも表記していて、主に鯨類をさす。
sen.e: Manyoshu contains poems writing about '鯨魚' Isana, which is also written as 鯨魚, 鯨名, 勇魚, 不知魚, and 伊佐魚, mainly indicating the whales.
The Manyoshu contains poems writing about isana, an expression which generally indicates whales, and which is written as 鯨魚, 鯨名, 勇魚, 不知魚, and 伊佐魚.

sen.j: そして「いさなとり」は、捕鯨を意味し主に海、浦、浜、灘などを表す枕詞として使われていた。
sen.e: And the word 'Inasatori', mainly meaning whale fishing, was mainly used as a set epithet to describe sea, inlet, beach, open sea and the like.

Yasumi shishi Waga Okimi no arigayo Naniwa no miya wa 'inasa-tori' Umi katazukite Tamairiu Hamae wo chikami asa wa furu namino otosawaku Yunagi ni Kaji no Oto kikoyu Akatoki no Nezame ni kikeba Watatsumi no Shioi no muta Urasu ni wa Chidori zuma yobi Ashibe ni wa Tazugane toyomu Miru hito no Katari ni sureba Kikuhito no Mimakurihorisuru mike mukau Ajiharanomiya ha Miredomo Akanu kamo (Naniwanomiya Palace where Our Okimi often goes is placed at the sea and near the beach to pick the balls; It could be heard the sound of waves in the morning as if birds shake their wings, the sound of oars in the evening; Keeping ears open at the dawn, birds sings to call my wife in a hidden reef appearing at low tide, canes cries in the reedy shore; when people hear about the palace from those who have seen it, they want to see it; it has seen enough of Ajiunomiya [also known as Naniwanomiya Palace])

sen.e: Relationship with foreign languages

Connections with other languages

sen.j: 1960年代には安田徳太郎が『万葉集の謎』に於いて日本語の祖語はインド北部レプチャ語であるとし、万葉集はレプチャ語で読めると主張していた。
sen.e: In 1960s, Tokutaro YASUDA stated in his book "Manyo no Nazo" that the parent language of the Japanese is the Rong in the northern part of India, and that Manyoshu can be read by the Rong.
In the 1960s, Tokutaro YASUDA stated in his book "Manyo no Nazo" that the parent language of Japanese is Rong from the northern part of India, and that the Manyoshu can be read by the Rong.

In the 1960s, Tokutaro YASUDA stated in his book "Manyo no Nazo" (Mystery of the Manyoshu) that the parent language of Japanese is Rong from the northern part of India, and that the Manyoshu can be read by the Rong.

sen.j: また、1980年代に、『万葉集』の言葉は古代朝鮮語と関係がある、又は、それにより解釈できるという意見が出され、一連の著作がベストセラーになったことがある。
sen.e: In 1980s, there proposed an opinion that the language used in "Manyoshu" is related with the ancient Korean, and that "Manyoshu" can be read by the ancient Korean, and a series of books related with the opinion made a big hit.

In the 1980s, it was suggested that the language used in the Manyoshu is related to ancient Korean, and that the Manyoshu could have been read by Koreans of that time, and a series of books about this theory became a bestseller.

In the 1980s, it was suggested that the language used in the "Manyoshu" is related to ancient Korean, and that the Manyoshu could have been read by Koreans of that time, and a series of books about this theory became a bestseller.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを補足しました。

sen.j: しかしながら、当時から日本語学の研究者の手によって徹底的な反論と批判がなされており、学界からは疑似科学・民間語源の一種（単なる言葉の偶然の類似）として受け止められ、近年ではまともに相手にもされていない。
sen.e: This opinion was thoroughly opposed and criticized by the Japanese language scholars from those days, and the Japanese language scholars have taken it as a kind of pseudoscience and folk etymology, i.e., merely a coincidence of languages, and no longer notice the opinion.

This idea was thoroughly opposed and criticized by the Japanese language scholars of the time, and it is taken as a kind of pseudoscience or folk etymology, i.e. merely a coincidence of languages, and it is no longer taken seriously.

This idea was thoroughly opposed and criticized by the Japanese language scholars of the time, and it is taken as a kind of pseudoscience or folk etymology, i.e. merely a coincidence of languages, and it is no longer taken seriously.

sen.j: 根底には、韓国併合を正当化しようとした「日鮮同祖」論。
sen.e: Behind the scene of this incident, there were 'Japan-Korea single ancestry theory';
The 'Japan-Korea single ancestry theory' was behind the motivation for the putting forward of this idea.
The 'Japan-Korea single ancestry theory' was behind the motivation for the putting forward of this idea.

sen.j: それを逆手にとった、日本の古代文化をすべて朝鮮半島由来とする韓国の民族主義（朴炳植、李寧煕など）、さらにそれに迎合する一部の日本人（藤村由加など）の言説や、それを好意的にとりあげた日本放送協会（ＮＨＫ。海外では「国営放送局」と認識され、国内以上に権威主義的な影響力がある）などマスメディア、文芸春秋社や新潮社など大手出版社の影響力が介在している。
sen.e: Korean nationalism that states that whole of the ancient Japanese culture originated from the Korean peninsula (Pak Pyong Sik, Yi Yong-hui); opinions of some Japanese people including Yuka FUJIMURA who went along with those view; and influences of mass media including Japan Broadcasting Corporation (NHK) that favorably reported that opinions of some Japanese people--NHK is recognized as a 'state-run broadcasting station' in abroad and has bigger authority in abroad than in Japan--and the major publishing houses including Bungeishunju Ltd. and Shincho Publ. Co.

Some Korean nationalist sentiments assert that the whole of ancient Japanese culture originated from the Korean Peninsula (put forward by Pak Pyong Sik and Yi Yong-hui), and some Japanese people including Yuka FUJIMURA have also supported those views, and elements of the media including the Japan Broadcasting Corporation (such as NHK, which is recognized as a respected state-run broadcasting station in other countries, in some ways moreso than in Japan) and major publishing houses including Bungeishunju Ltd. and Shincho Publishing Company have reported that those opinions have been shared by some Japanese people
sen.cmt: Largely rewritten. Changed for clarity. Some aspects of the content have been toned down to reflect the subjective nature of the content.
sen.e: Some Korean nationalist sentiments assert that the whole of ancient Japanese culture originated from the Korean Peninsula (put forward by Pak Pyong Sik and Yi Yong-hui), and some Japanese people including Yuka FUJIMURA have also supported those views, and elements of the media including the Japan Broadcasting Corporation (such as NHK, which is recognized as a respected state-run broadcasting station in other countries, in some ways moreso than in Japan) and major publishing houses including Bungeishunju Ltd. and Shincho Publishing Company have reported that those opinions have been shared by some Japanese people.
sen.cmt: ピリオドを補足しました。

sen.j: 多くの韓国人学者は、庶民も含む広範な文学の成立と固有言語の表記法が、自国よりもはるか以前の時期に日本において文献で確認できることに複雑な感情を抱いており、「古代朝鮮語」と『万葉集』の直結的関連性については、韓国の学界では科学的論証を経ずに肯定的に捉えられている。
sen.e: Most Korean scholars have mixed feelings to know that there is a document to prove that the literature and original writing system had been widely established including the commoners in Japan much earlier than in Korea; therefore, the Korean scholars favorably take the hypothesis of direct relationship between 'the ancient Korean language' and "Manyoshu" without any scientific evidence.

Many Korean scholars have mixed feelings in relation to documents which prove that literature and an original writing system had been widely established in Japan including for people outside the aristocracy much earlier than in Korea; therefore, some Korean scholars may prefer to adhere to hypothesis of direct relationship between 'the ancient Korean language' and the Manyoshu without concrete scientific evidence to back up the assertion.
sen.cmt: Word choice, grammar, changed for clarity.
sen.e: Many Korean scholars have mixed feelings in relation to documents which prove that literature and an original writing system had been widely established in Japan including for people outside the aristocracy much earlier than in Korea; therefore, some Korean scholars may prefer to adhere to hypothesis of direct relationship between 'the ancient Korean language' and the "Manyoshu" without concrete scientific evidence to back up the assertion.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを補足しました。

sen.j: しかし、従来の日本語的な解釈で『万葉集』を読むことを否定する論理的・合理的な根拠は全く存在せず、『万葉集』＝古代朝鮮語とする説は、学術的には完全に破綻しているといえよう。
sen.e: But there is not any logical and rational ground for denying the reading of "Manyoshu" by conventional Japanese understandings, which means that the opinion of taking "Manyoshu" the same as the ancient Korean language have technically collapsed.

However, there is no logical or rational ground for denying the conventional interpretation of the reading of the Manyoshu, which means that the idea of taking the Manyoshu as being derived from the ancient Korean language have technically collapsed.

However, there is no logical or rational ground for denying the conventional interpretation of the reading of the "Manyoshu," which means that the idea of taking the "Manyoshu" as being derived from the ancient Korean language have technically collapsed.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを補足しました。

sen.j: そもそも、『万葉集』を外国語と一致するとして日本語との関連性を追求する主張は、帝国主義的な拡張主義を正当化する論拠として、日本において明治時代以来頻繁に行われてきているものであり、特に目新しい主張というわけでもない。
sen.e: The view of pursuing the relationship between the foreign language with the Japanese based on the opinion that "Manyoshu" coincides with the foreign language has been frequently stated as the grounds for justifying the Japan's imperialistic expansionism after the Meiji period; therefore, there is not any novelty in the view.

The view of pursuing the relationship between other languages and the Japanese based on the opinion that the Manyoshu has many correlations with that language has been frequently stated in connection with the grounds for justifying Japan's imperialistic expansionism after the Meiji Period, and there is no novelty in this view.
